The statement "All the lights in Room A are on" is a universal affirmative statement, which means that it asserts the truth of a universal property (in this case, the property of being on) for all members of a set (in this case, the set of all lights in Room A).
The only way for this statement to be true is if every single light in Room A is indeed on. Therefore, it is not possible for any light in Room A to be off.
This means that statement (b) "No lights in Room A are off" MUST be true.
However, it is not necessary for at least one light in Room A to be on, since the statement only asserts that all lights are on, not that there is at least one light on.
Therefore, statement (a) "At least one light in Room A is on" is not necessarily true.
The correct answer is (b).
